seg.seg: ... emaciated by hunger (and) glowing (with) suffering like ...

... This the pretas heard. In their wish for food they soon became full of greed. They thought: a compassionate being (is offering us food (?)) ... They went to banish [their] suffering [, saying]: Let us go, Koṭikarṇa ...
In dem Wunsche nach Essen wurden sie [scil. die Pretas] schnell begierig.
Wishing for food, they [i.e. the pretas] soon became greedy.
... give us food, give us, oh lord, banish from us this suffering; (we [are] hungry. 78. Koṭikarṇa said:) I [am] hungry myself; from you I [would] beg such.
Ich [bin] selbst hungrig; von euch erbitte ich dieses.
I [am] hungry myself; of you I [would] ask this.
... Immediately the Pretas fell to earth as if struck, being slack in both shoulders, (asking him: oh lord,) whence [comes] your idea [to ...] from the Preta-city food ...
... 79. In [their] thousands the years have passed on us, the word “food” we have (not) heard (at all). We do not remember anyone who has seen food; not before
... (We are not able (?)) to give to you, [we who are] like skeletons dried from starving and for the reason of our own deeds imprisoned in the iron city. 80. Then he went (to) a second

(iron city). He stepped into the gate and called in a loud voice: water, water! Hoping for water the pretas went out, approaching in [their] thousands, taking up a body [posture] towards their throats: "Oh merciful master, give us water to drink!"
... 81. Without hope the pretas said: Truly, a thing very difficult to achieve [has] (been asked for by us). If out of compassion with us water is raining from the cloud, ...
If out of compassion with us water is raining from the cloud, …

... the [clear] sky comes back again immediately. By the reason of our deeds committed due to our miserliness (we [are] pretas). Whence should we give you water? 82. Thereupon he turned away [and] saw
… the [clear] sky comes back again.

(a palāśa-tree. He went towards it) yearning (for water). He found no water; he pulled off the leaves of the tree. These he ate. In the night there appeared beside the (tree) a man and a woman, sitting on couch spread there
Er [scil. Koṭikarṇa] fand kein Wasser, er riss sich die Blätter des Baumes ab. Das aß er.
He [i.e. Koṭikarṇa] found no water, he tore the leaves off the tree. That he ate.

... [and] relished in blessings of the heavenly kind. 83. The night became bright; the woman disappeared together with the bed and instead a dog appeared, with a great body, a horrifying [one]. He snatched at the man like a ... (?)
... genossen Glücksgüter nach himmlischer Art.
... enjoyed blessings of the heavenly kind.
Die Nacht wurde hell; zugleich mit dem Ruhebett verschwand die Frau.
The night was getting bright; together with the bed the woman disappeared.
... He tore open the cavity (of his belly) [and] ate him alive. Koṭikarṇa saw it [and] was disgusted. All the same he remained. At night he saw just that [again]. 84
Koṭikarṇa sah das [und] ekelte sich.
Koṭikarṇa saw this [and] was disgusted.

(Koṭikarṇa now asked the man: what was) your deed? By night you regale yourself like a king, by day you see hellish sufferings. The man said to him: did you know (the butcher) in the village Vāsagrāma?
Bei Nacht ergötzest du dich wie ein Gott, bei Tage siehst du h(öllische) Leiden.
In the night you regale yourself like a god, in the day[time] you see h(ellish) suffering.

(Koṭikarṇa affirmed this and the man continued: There was a butcher there), a cruel [one]. This one was I then. Because of pity Kātyāyana said (to me: 85.) Turn away (from killing sheep,) [my] dear! I did not obey. I said:
Aus Mitleid sprach Kātyāyana (zu mir: "Vom Schafetöten) kehre um, [mein] Lieber!" Ich aber fügte mich nicht. Ich sagte: ("Das ist mein Gewerbe, ich lebe davon."
Out of compassion, Kātyāyana spoke (to me: "From killing sheep) turn away, [my] dear!" But I did not obey. I said: ("This is my craft. I live on this.")

(This is my profession, I live by it. He said: Then kill by day), [but] by night keep the moral, so that you will not perish by that same thing! By night (I kept the moral, by day) I killed sheep. This is the effect of that. He asked: (Where
Keep the moral by night, so that you will not perish by that same thing!
Bei Nacht bewahre die Moralvorschrift!
At night, keep the moral rule!
do you want to go? and indicated to him the way to Vāsavagrāma. On the way) by day he saw (a second palāśa-tree), [and] a man [and] a woman appeared on a couch. Heavenly ...
